text:
Have you ever thought about what makes a human
corpse smell different than say, a dead bird
or pig?
Yeah, probably not.

But it’s a question being answered by forensic
scientists who are searching for ways to track
down missing bodies.

When disaster strikes—think earthquakes,
mud slides, forest fires, terrorist attacks—the

first order of business is, of course, to
find and save survivors.
But often there are fatalities.

It’s essential to find these missing bodies
to bring closure to family members, to allow

for a proper funeral, and, sometimes, to crack
unsolved murders.
But how to find these missing corpses?
Well, with properly trained cadaver dogs.

These canines can detect human corpses under
rubble, mud, and even water by sniffing out

volatile compounds unique to decomposing human
bodies.
Meet Inca.

This is her chasing the scent of underwater
human remains.

And here she is swimming in a figure-eight
pattern to communicate that the scent is strongest
right beneath her.

When she was just an 18-month old pup, Inca
and her trainer joined a California disaster

response team to track down people who had
died in their homes as forest fires ravaged
the state.
Not all cadaver dogs are as good as Inca.

She was trained using actual decomposing human
remains.

In some countries, though, it’s illegal
to possess human remains.

In these countries, trainers turn to decomposing
animals such as pigs to train cadaver dogs.

Which means the dogs are excellent at finding
dead pigs, but not necessarily as adept with
human corpses.

If scientists could figure out the chemical
cocktail that makes up the scent of human

corpses, trainers wouldn’t need to use proxies—or
real human parts.
They could just use the synthetic scent instead.

Not only would it be easier to properly train
cadaver dogs, but researchers could build

electronic noses that might also be deployed
in disaster areas, say on a drone.

But finding the precise chemicals that are
unique to human decomposition turns out to
be tougher than you would think.

If you’ve watched an orange rot in a fruit
bowl, you know that decomposition is a complicated
and dynamic process.

Decomposition in humans kicks off when a person’s
own enzymes and microbiome start breaking
down the body.

Then inhabitants of the nearby environment—such
as bacteria, insects, animals, you name it--join
the macabre feast.

Among the hundreds of different chemicals
floating off a human corpse over time, some

of the most commonly measured molecules include
two aromatic hydrocarbons, toluene and p-xylene,

as well as dimethyl disulfide, which has a
disagreeable garlicky odor.

Curiously, putrescine and cadaverine--the
most famous “dead body smell” chemicals--aren’t
always measured in the air around a corpse.

They may be present within the corpse as a
result of bacterial metabolism but they don’t
always become volatile and escape.

To further complicate matters for scientists
hunting the scent of death, the place where

a body decomposes—the desert, underwater,
inside a cement block--can modify death’s aroma.

Even a person’s lifelong diet makes an appearance
post-mortem.

Researchers sometimes measure fluorinated
compounds percolating off human corpses, such
as trichlorofluoromethane.

This likely shows up because a person drank
fluoridated water.

Scientists are still a ways away from finding
the true scent of death because accounting

for all the variables contributing to odor
requires enough data from different environments
to achieve statistical certainty.
Which means a lot of cadavers.

In addition to the extensive ethical and legal
permissions required to work with human corpses,

there’s a lot of competition for the cadavers
donated to science.

And not a lot of people donate their bodies
specifically to the study of postmortem aromas.
But what about you?
Would you donate your body to forensic science?
Tell us in the comments.
And thanks for watching.

If you want more chemistry videos, make sure
to hit the subscribe button.
